title: 107_hr1623
content: The Act may be cited as the "Historically Women's Public Colleges or Universities Historic Building Restoration and Preservation Act". SEC. 2. DEFINITIONS. This section defines key terms used in the Act, including "historically women's public college or university," "historic building or structure," and "Secretary." Preservation and restoration grants are provided for historic buildings and structures at historically women's public colleges or universities. The Secretary awards grants to historically women's public colleges or universities for preserving and restoring historic buildings using funds from the National Historic Preservation Act. Grantees must agree not to alter the property without the Secretary's approval. Grantees must agree not to alter the property without the Secretary's approval, and provide public access for interpretive and educational purposes. Matching funds may be required for buildings listed on the National Register of Historic Places. The Secretary may provide funds for grants related to historic buildings listed on the National Register of Historic Places, with the grantee required to contribute 50% of the program costs from non-Federal sources. In-kind contributions of property or personnel are also accepted in addition to cash payments. Funding provisions state that up to $16,000,000 for each fiscal year from 2002 to 2006 can be allocated for grants under the program, with $2,000,000 earmarked for grants in fiscal year 2002. In-kind contributions of property or personnel services can be used for the non-Federal share of costs required. For fiscal year 2002, $2,000,000 is available for grants under the program, allocated to specific universities in different states. For fiscal year 2002, specific universities in different states will receive grants under the program, with allocations to institutions like Winthrop University, University of Montevallo, Texas Woman's University, University of Science and Arts of Oklahoma, and Wesleyan College. If less than $16,000,000 is available, funding to these institutions will be reduced equally. Funds will also be allocated for fiscal years 2003-2006. Funds will also be distributed for fiscal years 2003-2006 to eligible institutions named in the program. The Secretary will create necessary regulations to implement the Act.
